questions.text: The Live Attenuated H1N1 Influenza vaccine is administered by which route? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Intranasal

 

  • Live attenuated influenza vaccines are administered through the intranasal route. This provides immunity at the site where respiratory viruses normally enter the body. 
  • Live attenuated vaccines like H1N1 Live typically engage mucosal surfaces to produce both local (IgA) and systemic (IgG) immunity. 
  • The intranasal administration mimics the natural route of infection for influenza viruses, stimulating a more comprehensive immune response than parenteral routes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intramuscular: Intramuscular route is typically used for killed/inactivated vaccines, including inactivated influenza vaccines. The H1N1 Killed vaccine would be administered through this route, not the live attenuated version. Intramuscular administration bypasses the respiratory mucosa where influenza viruses naturally replicate.

 

Option C. Subcutaneous: Subcutaneous administration is primarily used for certain killed vaccines and toxoids. Live viral vaccines targeting respiratory pathogens would not achieve optimal mucosal immunity through this route, making it inappropriate for live attenuated influenza vaccines.

 

Option D. Intradermal: Intradermal route is used for specific vaccines like BCG and fractional IPV. This route provides limited exposure to mucosal surfaces and would not be effective for respiratory virus vaccines that require replication in the respiratory tract to generate proper immunity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Live attenuated vaccines are designed to mimic natural infection, and for respiratory pathogens like influenza, intranasal administration provides direct access to respiratory mucosa where the virus naturally replicates, producing both mucosal and systemic immunity.

questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with dilated tortuous veins in the leg. He had a history of trauma 10 years back in the same limb. On examination, the dilated tortuous vein showed pulsatility. Most likely diagnosis in this patient will be? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) AV fistula

 

An arteriovenous (AV) fistula is an abnormal connection between an artery and a vein. The history of trauma in the same limb suggests a possible traumatic AV fistula. The presence of pulsatility in the veins is a key indicator, as it implies that arterial pressure is being transmitted to the veins. This is not typical for varicose veins, aneurysms, or hemangiomas, making AV fistula the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicose vein: Varicose veins are typically dilated, tortuous veins caused by incompetent valves but do not show pulsatility.

 

Option B. Aneurysm: Aneurysms involve arterial dilation and do not present with pulsatile veins.

 

Option C. Hemangioma: Hemangiomas are benign tumors of blood vessels, usually presenting as a mass and not associated with pulsatile veins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A history of trauma with the presence of dilated tortuous veins showing pulsatility strongly indicates an arteriovenous fistula due to the transmission of arterial pulsation to the veins

questions.text: A patient has mental retardation, seizures, thrombotic state, amino acid metabolism disorder, osteoporosis, and ectopia lentis. Which vitamin must be supplemented to the patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6

 

The clinical presentation, including mental retardation, seizures, a thrombotic state, osteoporosis, and ectopia lentis, is characteristic of homocystinuria.

 

Homocystinuria is a genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS), an enzyme involved in methionine metabolism. This deficiency leads to an accumulation of homocysteine, which can cause a wide range of symptoms, including neurodevelopmental issues, skeletal abnormalities, and vascular complications.

 

Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) is crucial in the management of homocystinuria, as it is a cofactor for CBS. Supplementation with vitamin B6 can enhance the activity of the residual enzyme, helping to reduce homocysteine levels in responsive patients, thus mitigating the symptoms and reducing the risk of complications such as thrombosis.

 

Note –

 

The causes of ectopia lentis include several conditions, such as Marfan's syndrome, homocystinuria, Weill-Marchesani syndrome, and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. These are important to remember when identifying the underlying cause of lens dislocation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B12: While vitamin B12 is also involved in homocysteine metabolism, deficiencies in B12 are not directly related to the presentation seen in homocystinuria. B12 supplementation is more relevant to other conditions such as pernicious anemia or when correcting elevated homocysteine due to B12 deficiency, but it is not the primary treatment for homocystinuria.

 

Option C. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) is not involved in the metabolic pathway of homocysteine. It plays a role in carbohydrate metabolism and is associated with conditions like Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and beriberi but not with homocystinuria.

 

Option D. Vitamin B2: Riboflavin (vitamin B2) is not directly related to the symptoms of homocystinuria or the management of this disorder. It is mainly involved in energy production and the metabolism of fats, drugs, and steroids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Homocystinuria is characterized by ectopia lentis, thrombotic state, mental retardation, and seizures, among other features. Vitamin B6 supplementation is essential in managing this condition by aiding the function of the deficient enzyme cystathionine beta-synthase.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with spinal TB; he has a swelling in the left groin with limb attitude is in flexion. Identify what caused it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario of a patient with Pott spine having persistent hip flexion with a history of spinal tuberculosis is suggestive of psoas abscess involving the psoas muscle, marked A in the given coronal CT image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with spinal TB, a psoas abscess is a significant complication that can lead to symptoms such as groin swelling and changes in limb posture due to its location and the effect of the abscess on the surrounding structures, particularly the psoas muscle. Prompt recognition and treatment are crucial to manage symptoms and prevent further complications.

questions.text: Identify the drug used to treat the condition shown below: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Anti-tubercular therapy

 

  • The image showing a plaque with one margin extending & other margin healing with scarring (Asymmetrical lesion), this favors to the diagnosis of lupus vulgaris, which is treated using anti-tubercular drugs.
  • It is the most common cutaneous tuberculosis in adults in India.
  • It occurs in previously sensitized hosts with good immunity.
  • Granulomas with little to no caseation can be seen on histology.

 

Lupus Vulgaris

 

  • Lupus vulgaris is a chronic form of skin TB seen in patients with moderate immunity to TB bacilli
  • It is seen more common in females.

 

Pathogenesis:

 

  • It occurs due to hematogenous, lymphatic, or contiguous spread from elsewhere in the body, or from exogenous inoculation. It occurs in previously sensitized hosts with good immunity, hence Paucibacillary.

 

Clinical features

 

  • It presents as single or few lesions which are well demarcated, annular plaques which extend centrifugally. Periphery show erythematous deep-seated nodules which on diascopy may stand out as apple jelly nodules as seen in the image below.

 

 

  •  They are most commonly seen in buttocks, upper extremities, and face. Center is depigmented with paper-thin scar with nodules.
  • Papules may recur on the scarred areas, which enlarge and coalesce. This leads to the formation of large, firm, elevated plaques.

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Histologic examination & a positive culture for M. tuberculosis/ bovis confirm the diagnosis
  • Most prominent histopathologic feature: Typical granulomas with scanty or absent caseation.

 

Complication

 

  • Secondary scarring & squamous cell carcinomas may develop rarely.

 

Treatment:

Anti-tubercular drugs.

 

CLASSIFICATION OF CUTANEOUS TUBERCULOSIS IS BASED ON THE MODE OF ACQUISITION:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical steroids therapy:

  • This is not the appropriate treatment for lupus vulgaris.
  • Topical steroids are used for inflammatory conditions, and while they may reduce inflammation and symptoms temporarily, they do not address the underlying mycobacterial infection that causes lupus vulgaris.

 

Option B. Anti-leprosy treatment:

  • Although leprosy is also caused by a mycobacterium (Mycobacterium leprae) and anti-leprosy drugs are used to treat it, the clinical features described do not match leprosy.
  • Moreover, the treatment regimens for leprosy and tuberculosis are different.

 

Option C. Anti-fungal therapy:

  • Fungal infections can present with skin lesions, but the description of the lesion as characteristic of lupus vulgaris does not fit a fungal infection.
  • Anti-fungal therapy would not be effective against mycobacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis characterized by irregular plaques that show progression at one margin and healing with scarring at another, and to understand that the appropriate treatment is a multi-drug anti-tubercular therapy regimen.

 

References:

 

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 27.21-27.23, 32.35-32.36, 33.44-33.45

choices.text: Human T-lymphotropic Virus 1 (HTLV-1) and Adult T-cell Leukemia
Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) and Diffuse B-Cell Lymphoma

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of infectious agents and their associated malignancies is incorrectly matched? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and Lymphoplasmacytic Lymphoma.

 

Explanation:

 

HHV-8 is not associated with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma. HHV-8 is associated with primary effusion lymphoma and multicentric Castleman's disease. Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma (Waldenström macroglobulinemia) is associated with hepatitis C virus, not HHV-8, as shown in the infectious associations of lymphoid malignancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) and Burkitt's Lymphoma: EBV is strongly associated with endemic (African) Burkitt's lymphoma, where it can be found in nearly all cases, while most non-endemic BLs are EBV negative.

 

Option B. Human T-lymphotropic Virus 1 (HTLV-1) and Adult T-cell Leukemia: HTLV-1 directly leads to adult T-cell lymphoma/leukemia (ATL) in a small percentage of infected individuals. The virus is transmitted through breast milk from infected mothers.

 

Option C. Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) and Diffuse B-Cell Lymphoma: HIV infection predisposes patients to developing aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, including diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infectious agents can play significant roles in the pathogenesis of specific lymphoid malignancies, but each has characteristic associations that are important for understanding disease etiology and treatment approaches.

questions.text: Cutaneous larva migrans is most commonly caused by which organism? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ancylostoma braziliense

 

Cutaneous larva migrans is most commonly caused by Ancylostoma braziliense.

 

Cutaneous larva migrans or ground itch or creeping eruption is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

The most common cause is non-human species of Hookworm Ancylostoma braziliense and A. caninum.

 

Larva currens – Strongyloides stercolaris

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strongyloides stercolaris: Incorrect, although Strongyloides stercolaris can cause skin symptoms (known as larva currens) due to the rapid migration of larvae, it is not the most common cause of cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Option B. Toxocara canis: Incorrect, this organism causes toxocariasis or visceral larva migrans, primarily affecting organs and causing systemic symptoms, rather than the localized skin manifestations seen in cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Option D. Necator americanus: Incorrect, this is a human hookworm that primarily causes gastrointestinal symptoms upon infection, not cutaneous larva migrans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ancylostoma braziliense is the primary cause of cutaneous larva migrans, a condition where the migration of hookworm larvae in the skin results in distinctive creeping eruptions. This condition is a reminder of the zoonotic potential of certain parasites and underscores the importance of preventive measures, especially in areas where pets are likely to be infected.

choices.text: Components of MELD (Model for end stage liver disease) scoring system are creatinine, bilirubin, INR, serum sodium (mEq/L).
Components of CTP (Child Turcotte Pugh) score are albumin, bilirubin, INR, ascites, encephalopathy.
Components of CTP (Child Turcotte Pugh) are creatinine, bilirubin, and INR.
MELD score is used to assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation.

questions.text: Which among the following is false? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Components of CTP (Child Turcotte Pugh) are creatinine, bilirubin, and INR

 

Statement C is false. The Child Turcotte Pugh (CTP) score does not include creatinine as a component. Instead, CTP uses the following parameters to assess the severity of liver disease: bilirubin, albumin, INR, ascites, and encephalopathy. This score is traditionally used to evaluate the prognosis in chronic liver disease, primarily cirrhosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Components of MELD scoring system are creatinine, bilirubin, INR, serum sodium (mEq/L): This statement is true. The MELD score has been updated to include serum sodium along with creatinine, bilirubin, and INR to improve its accuracy in predicting mortality risk in liver transplant candidates.

 

Option B. Components of CTP score are albumin, bilirubin, INR, ascites, encephalopathy: This is accurate and reflects the correct components of the CTP score.

 

Option D. MELD score is used to assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation: This is true. The MELD score is widely used to prioritize patients for liver transplantation based on their risk of death from liver disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MELD-Na components mnemonic “CBI”

 

C - Creatinine

B - Bilirubin

I - INR + Sodium

 

CTP score mnemonic BANANa

 

  • Bilirubin Albumin INR Ascites eNcephalopathy

 

Reference - Harrison/Cirrhosis/Chap 344

questions.text: Arrow-headed fingers on X-ray is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A (Acromegaly)

 

Explanation: 

 

Acromegaly is characterized by "spade phalanx" appearance of the fingers on X-ray, which presents as an arrow-headed appearance. This condition results from growth hormone (GH) overproduction in adults, with pituitary adenoma being the most common cause. The excessive GH leads to bony overgrowth and soft tissue enlargement, particularly affecting the hands and creating the distinctive spade-shaped appearance of the terminal phalanges.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperparathyroidism - Hyperparathyroidism causes subperiosteal bone resorption, particularly on the radial side of the middle phalanges of the index and middle fingers, as well as bone demineralization. The cortex appears "shaggy" with irregular margins, not arrow-headed.

 

Option C. Hyperthyroidism - Hyperthyroidism is not associated with characteristic bone changes in the fingers resembling arrow-headed appearance. While thyroid disorders may affect bone metabolism, they do not cause the specific radiographic finding described in the question.

 

Option D. Hyperprolactinemia - Hyperprolactinemia is not associated with any specific bone changes in the fingers. Its clinical manifestations include galactorrhea, amenorrhea, and infertility, without the skeletal manifestations like arrow-headed fingers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acromegaly causes distinctive hand changes including spade-shaped phalanges (arrow-headed fingers) on X-ray, along with other radiographic findings including increased heel pad thickness, prognathism, expanded sinuses, and calvarial thickening.

questions.text: A female presented with a long history of fever, discolored skin of lower limbs, and lower limb edema. Microscopic examination showed a sheathed organism with no nuclei at the tip of the tail. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wuchereria bancrofti

 

Wuchereria bancrofti is a filarial worm responsible for lymphatic filariasis, which often presents with symptoms such as prolonged fever, discolored skin, and limb edema due to lymphatic blockage. Microscopic examination of the organism reveals a sheathed microfilaria with no nuclei at the tip of the tail, which is characteristic of Wuchereria bancrofti.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mansonella: Mansonella species are generally unsheathed microfilariae and do not match the description of having no nuclei at the tail tip, making this an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option C. Loa loa: Loa loa, also known as the African eye worm, is a sheathed microfilaria that has continuous nuclei to the very end of the tail, which distinguishes it from Wuchereria bancrofti.

 

Option D. Brugia malayi: Brugia malayi is another sheathed filarial worm but is characterized by having nuclei at the tail tip, typically in two distinct spots, unlike Wuchereria bancrofti, which has none.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with symptoms of lymphatic filariasis and a sheathed microfilaria with no tail tip nuclei, Wuchereria bancrofti is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: Conjunctival xerosis is associated with which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

Conjunctival xerosis, which refers to the drying and thickening of the conjunctiva, is indeed associated with Vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A is crucial for maintaining the health of epithelial tissues, including those of the eye. This deficiency can lead to various ocular manifestations, including night blindness and xerophthalmia, of which conjunctival xerosis is a part.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency is primarily associated with conditions related to bone health, such as rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. Conjunctival xerosis is not a recognized consequence of Vitamin D deficiency.

 

Option B. Vitamin K: Vitamin K deficiency is primarily associated with bleeding disorders due to impaired blood clotting. While Vitamin K deficiency can lead to bleeding in various tissues, conjunctival xerosis is not a recognized consequence of this deficiency.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency can lead to scurvy, which is characterized by symptoms such as bleeding gums, easy bruising, and impaired wound healing. However, conjunctival xerosis is not a typical manifestation of Vitamin C deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conjunctival xerosis is specifically associated with Vitamin A deficiency and is a significant indicator of this deficiency, affecting the epithelial tissues of the eye.

questions.text: Which joint allows for the side-to-side movement of the head, enabling a person to look to the right and left?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atlanto-axial

 

  • The movements at the atlanto-axial joint allow a person to look left and right.
  • The atlanto-axial joints consist of two lateral joints located on either side between the bottom of the atlas bone and the top of the axis bone, which are flat joints.
  • Additionally, there is a central joint between the dens (a protrusion from the axis bone) and the front arch and transverse ligament of the atlas, which is a pivot joint.
  • This central joint has two distinct synovial cavities - one in the front and one in the back.
  • Rotatory movements occur at all three joints and revolve around a vertical axis.
  • The dens acts as a pivot around which the atlas rotates (carrying the skull with it), allowing the head to rotate side to side.
  • The alar ligaments restrict movement. Atlanto-axial rotation has a normal range of about 40°.

 

Atlanto-Axial joint

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atlanto-occipital joint: This joint is formed between the first cervical vertebra (the atlas or C1) and the occipital bone of the skull. It primarily permits the "nodding" motion of the head, as in signaling "yes". This joint allows for flexion and extension of the head, but not significant rotation. It's the joint that lets you tilt your head upward or downward.

 

Option C. C2-C3 joint: This joint is between the second and third cervical vertebrae. While it does allow for some degree of rotation, it does not provide the primary rotational movement to look right or left. The range of motion at this joint is less compared to the atlanto-axial joint, and it's more involved in flexion, extension, and some lateral bending.

 

Option D. C3-C4 joint: This joint is between the third and fourth cervical vertebrae. Like the C2-C3 joint, the C3-C4 joint also provides some degree of rotation but not the primary movement. Its main movements are flexion, extension, and lateral bending of the neck. The lower down the cervical spine you go, the less rotational capacity there typically is at each subsequent joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atlanto-axial joint is formed between the first cervical vertebra (the atlas or C1) and the second cervical vertebra (the axis or C2). The dens or odontoid process, fits into the atlas, allowing for a pivot-like rotation. This is the joint responsible for allowing the rotation of the head from side to side, as in signaling "no" or looking right and left. It provides the majority of the rotational capability of the head.

questions.text: A patient experienced difficulty maintaining balance immediately after a roller coaster ride. Which of the following is most likely involved in the normal balance mechanism?(FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vestibulospinal tract

 

The vestibulospinal tract is responsible for maintaining balance and posture. It originates from the vestibular nuclei in the brainstem and plays a crucial role in equilibrium. When balance is disrupted, as in this case after a roller coaster ride, the vestibulospinal tract helps in regaining postural stability by:

 

  • Receiving input from the vestibular apparatus
  • Coordinating with antigravity muscles
  • Making postural adjustments to maintain balance
  • Working with the vestibular system for maintaining equilibrium

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rubrospinal tract: (Incorrect)

 

  • This tract is part of the extrapyramidal system
  • It helps in flexor muscle control
  • Not primarily involved in balance maintenance
  • Works with rubrospinal tract and reticulospinal tract for gross motor movements

 

Option C. Corticospinal tract: (Incorrect)

 

  • This is the main motor pathway for voluntary movements
  • Originates from the motor cortex
  • Not directly involved in balance maintenance
  • Controls fine, skilled movements

 

Option D. Reticulospinal tract: (Incorrect)

 

  • Part of the extrapyramidal system
  • Involved in autonomic functions and crude movements
  • While it contributes to posture, it's not the primary tract for balance
  • Originates from reticular formation

 

Educational Objective:

 

The vestibulospinal tract is primarily responsible for maintaining balance and posture by integrating vestibular system input and facilitating extensor muscle activity to stabilize the body during motion and positional changes. It plays a crucial role in postural adjustments following vestibular disturbances, such as those experienced after rapid or erratic motion, like a roller coaster ride.

questions.text: A patient had a pulmonary mass which shows IHC staining with TTF-1 as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenocarcinoma lung

 

Thyroid Transcription Factor-1 (TTF-1) is a nuclear protein that is a specific marker for adenocarcinoma of the lung and small cell carcinoma of the lung. However, it is most commonly associated with adenocarcinoma.

 

TTF-1 positivity indicates that the tumor cells are likely of lung or thyroid origin, with adenocarcinoma being the most common type of lung cancer associated with this marker.

 

Additionally, other markers like Napsin A and surfactant protein A1 are also specific to adenocarcinoma of the lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell cancer lung: Squamous cell carcinoma typically shows markers like P63, P40, or keratin. It does not stain positive for TTF-1, differentiating it from adenocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Small cell carcinoma lung: While TTF-1 can be positive in small cell carcinoma, other specific markers such as chromogranin, synaptophysin, and INSM-1 are more indicative. TTF-1's presence alone, along with the given context, makes adenocarcinoma the more likely diagnosis.

 

Option D. Large cell carcinoma lung: This is generally a diagnosis of exclusion and does not have specific immunohistochemical markers like TTF-1. Large cell carcinoma is generally a diagnosis of exclusion, as it lacks specific markers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TTF-1 is a key immunohistochemical marker that strongly suggests adenocarcinoma of the lung, particularly when observed in a pulmonary mass.

questions.text: The ureteric bud arises from which of the following embryological structures? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mesonephric duct

 

The ureteric bud arises from the mesonephric (or Wolffian) duct. The mesonephric duct is one of the primary structures in the early embryonic development of the urinary and reproductive systems. The ureteric bud's growth is stimulated by signals from the adjacent metanephrogenic blastema. The ureteric bud undergoes repeated branching to form the ureter, renal pelvis, calyces, and the collecting tubules of the kidneys.

 

  • The intermediate mesoderm is a specific type of mesoderm that is located between the paraxial mesoderm and lateral plate.
  • During development, it plays a crucial role in the formation of both the urogenital system and the reproductive system. It divides into two structures known as the genital ridge and nephrogenic cord.
  • The nephrogenic cord goes on to form three distinct structures - the pronephros, mesonephros, and metanephros. From the mesonephros, the ureteric bud develops and eventually fuses with the mesonephric duct.
  • The metanephros then proliferates around the ureteric bud, forming what is called the metanephric blastema. This ultimately gives rise to the definitive kidneys.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metanephros: The metanephros is the embryological structure that develops into the permanent kidney in humans. The metanephrogenic blastema (or metanephrogenic mesenchyme) is the tissue that surrounds the tip of the ureteric bud and interacts with it. Signals from the ureteric bud stimulate the metanephrogenic blastema to differentiate into the nephron components of the kidney (like the glomerulus, proximal tubule, loop of Henle, etc.). The metanephros is not the origin of the ureteric bud but rather interacts with it.

 

Option C. Pronephros: The pronephros is the most primitive of the three embryonic kidneys. It appears early in embryonic development but quickly degenerates and is non-functional in mammals. Its duct, the pronephric duct, eventually becomes the mesonephric duct when the mesonephros starts to develop. The pronephros itself does not give rise to the ureteric bud.

 

Option D. Genital sinus: The genital sinus is involved in the development of the lower parts of the reproductive system and parts of the urinary system. In females, it contributes to parts of the vagina, and in males, it contributes to parts of the urethra. It does not give rise to the ureteric bud.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

A. Dorsal views of the bladder showing the relation of the ureters and mesonephric ducts during development. Initially the ureters are formed by an outgrowth of the mesonephric duct

 

B-D. with time they assume a separate entrance into the urinary bladder

 

C and D. Note the trigone of the bladder formed by incorporation of the mesonephric ducts

questions.text: Sudden loss of vision without fundal glow without history of trauma is caused by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitreous hemorrhage

 

Vitreous hemorrhage is characterized by sudden loss of vision and absence of fundal glow without a history of trauma. This occurs because blood in the vitreous cavity blocks light from reaching the retina, preventing visualization of the fundus and causing vision loss. The sudden onset and lack of fundal glow are key diagnostic features of vitreous hemorrhage.

 

 

Causes of Vitreous hemorrhage:

 

  • Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR)
  • Eales Disease
  • Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO)
  • Post trauma

 

Treatment:

 

  • Initial Step: Patients should maintain a propped-up position to help settle the blood within the eye.
  • Natural Resolution: Wait for the hemorrhage to clear up spontaneously, as many cases resolve without intervention.
  • Surgical Treatment: If the hemorrhage does not resolve naturally and vision remains impaired, a vitrectomy may be performed. This surgery involves removing the blood-filled vitreous and replacing it with a saline solution to restore the eye's shape and function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute congestive glaucoma: While this can cause sudden vision loss, it typically doesn't result in complete loss of fundal glow. The fundus may appear hazy due to corneal edema, but it's usually still visible to some extent.

 

Option C. Optic atrophy: This condition leads to gradual vision loss rather than sudden loss. Moreover, the fundus and optic disc would still be visible during examination, allowing for clear visualization of the atrophied optic nerve.

 

Option D. Acute anterior uveitis: This primarily affects the front part of the eye and doesn't typically cause sudden, severe vision loss or loss of fundal glow unless there are extensive inflammatory membranes in the pupillary area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sudden loss of vision combined with absence of fundal glow, without a history of trauma, is highly characteristic of vitreous hemorrhage. This condition requires prompt evaluation to determine the underlying cause, which could include proliferative diabetic retinopathy, Eales disease, central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO), or other vascular abnormalities of the retina

questions.text: The following image shows which X-ray view?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Towne’s view

 

Based on the image provided, where the X-ray beam is directed from above the skull at an angle and the detector is positioned below the skull, the indicated X-ray view is consistent with the Towne’s view.

 

Towne’s view is an X-ray where the beam is angled at approximately 30 degrees to the orbitomeatal line and directed downward toward the patient's head, which is positioned with the chin lifted. This view is particularly useful for assessing the occipital bone, posterior fossa, and foramen magnum, as well as the mastoid and middle ear structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water's view is an X-ray taken with the patient's head tilted backward so that the X-ray beam is directed perpendicularly to the orbitomeatal line. It's often used to visualize the maxillary sinuses, the orbits, and the nasal cavity.

 

Option B. Caldwell view is performed with the patient’s head positioned such that the X-ray beam is angled at 15-20 degrees to the orbitomeatal line and the central ray is directed towards the nose. This view is used to visualize the frontal sinuses, orbits, and ethmoid sinuses.

 

Option D. Schuller’s view is an X-ray that provides a lateral view of the skull, specifically to evaluate the mastoid air cells and the structure of the temporal bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Towne’s view X-ray is used to visualize the occipital bone, posterior fossa, foramen magnum, and mastoid process by positioning the patient with the head tilted upward and the X-ray beam angled approximately 30 degrees to the orbitomeatal line.

questions.text: What is the dose of Ulipristal used in emergency contraception? (NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 30 mg

 

Explanation:

 

The dose of Ulipristal in emergency contraception is 30 mg to be taken within 72 hrs (can be taken upto 120hrs).

 

The following can be used as emergency contraceptives:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dose of Ulipristal for emergency contraception is 30 mg, to be taken within 72 hours (up to 120 hours) after unprotected intercourse.

 

Ref: Page no 630, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: The Van Nuys grading system for ductal carcinoma in situ does not include:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hormone receptor staining

 

Hormone receptor status, which determines if the tumor cells have receptors for hormones like estrogen and progesterone, is not included in the VNPI. While hormone receptor status is crucial for managing invasive breast cancers, as it determines potential responses to hormone therapies like tamoxifen, it's not a component of the Van Nuys grading system for DCIS.

 

Staining for estrogen and progesterone receptors is not part of the Van Nuys system used for grading DCIS.

 

The Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) is a grading system that helps to stratify patients with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) based on several factors to determine the likelihood of recurrence and guide treatment decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age of the patient: The age of the patient is one of the factors in the Van Nuys Prognostic Index. Younger age (below 40) is associated with a higher risk of recurrence.

 

Option B. Size of the tumor: Tumor size is an essential factor in the Van Nuys grading system. Larger DCIS lesions (> 4cm) are associated with a higher risk of recurrence. Thus, the size can influence the treatment approach.

 

Option D. Presence of necrosis: In DCIS, the presence or absence of necrosis plays a role in determining the prognosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Van Nuys grading system for ductal carcinoma in situ does not include Hormone receptor staining.

questions.text: In measurement of rifled barrel weapon, caliber depends on: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Distance between two opposite lands

 

Explanation:

 

In a rifled firearm, the barrel's interior has alternating projecting parts called lands and the adjacent parts called grooves. The caliber of a rifled barrel weapon is defined as the distance between two opposite lands, which represents the diameter of the rifled firearm.

 

 

This is different from a smooth bore firearm, where the diameter is simply called the bore, as there are no lands or grooves present.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Distance between two opposite grooves: The distance between two opposite grooves is not used to determine the caliber of a rifled barrel weapon. The caliber is measured between the lands, not the grooves.

 

Option. C. Number of lead pellets: The number of lead pellets is not related to the caliber of a rifled barrel weapon. Lead pellets are typically associated with shotguns, which have smooth bore barrels.

 

Option. D. Mass and velocity: While the mass and velocity of a projectile are important factors in the performance of a firearm, they do not determine the caliber of a rifled barrel weapon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The caliber of a rifled barrel weapon is determined by the distance between two opposite lands, which represents the diameter of the rifled firearm's barrel. This is different from a smooth bore firearm, where the diameter is simply called the bore.

questions.text: During a surgical procedure on a patient exhibiting symptoms indicative of peritonitis, a diverticular rupture is observed, accompanied by fecal peritonitis. What would be the corresponding stage according to the Hinchey's classification? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stage 4

 

Hinchey's Classification is used to describe the severity of perforated diverticular disease. It helps guide the management of diverticulitis by categorizing the condition into different stages based on the clinical presentation and severity of the disease.

 

Hinchey's Classification Stages:

 

  • Stage 0: Mild clinical diverticulitis with symptoms such as left lower quadrant abdominal pain, low-grade fever, and leukocytosis. Management typically includes oral antibiotics.
  • Stage Ia: Confined pericolic inflammation or phlegmon. This stage can be managed with antibiotics, with or without CT-guided drainage.
  • Stage Ib: Confined pericolic abscess. Similar to Stage Ia, management includes antibiotics, with or without CT-guided drainage.
  • Stage II: Distant abscess. This requires abscess drainage, often through percutaneous methods.
  • Stage III: Purulent peritonitis. This stage involves the presence of pus in the peritoneal cavity, usually managed with Hartmann's surgery.
  • Stage IV: Fecal peritonitis. This stage indicates the presence of fecal matter in the peritoneal cavity due to a perforated diverticulum, and it is managed with Hartmann's surgery.

 

In the given scenario, the patient has a diverticular rupture with fecal peritonitis, which corresponds to Stage IV in Hinchey's classification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage 1: Stage 1 is divided into Stage Ia and Stage Ib. Stage Ia involves confined pericolic inflammation or phlegmon, while Stage Ib involves a confined pericolic abscess. Neither of these stages includes peritonitis.

 

Option B. Stage 2: Stage 2 involves the presence of a distant abscess. This stage does not include peritonitis and is managed with abscess drainage.

 

Option C. Stage 3: Stage 3 involves purulent peritonitis, which includes the presence of pus in the peritoneal cavity. However, it does not involve fecal contamination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hinchey's Classification of diverticulitis is essential for determining the appropriate management strategy. Stage IV in Hinchey's classification corresponds to fecal peritonitis, which requires immediate surgical intervention, typically Hartmann's surgery.

questions.text: A child with infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis has multiple episodes of non-bilious vomiting. Which of the following metabolic abnormalities is likely to be seen in this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypochloremic, hypokalemic alkalosis

 

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) is a condition where there is constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet due to hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus. This results in persistent vomiting, which leads to the loss of hydrogen and chloride ions in the gastric acid and potassium ions in the gastric mucus. As a consequence, the multiple episodes of non-bilious vomiting in IHPS can cause hypochloremia and hypokalemia, leading to alkalosis.

 

Cause of metabolic alkalosis: The hydrogen ions that normally reach the duodenum are now lost due to vomiting. Hence, the bicarbonate secretion from the pancreas is decreased, thereby increasing the bicarbonate levels in the serum.

 

Causes of hypokalemia:

 

  • Because of alkalosis, the hydrogen ions exit from the cells in exchange for potassium leading to hypokalemia.
  • Loss of fluid due to excessive vomiting activates the RAAS pathway. This worsens hypokalemia as the aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for the secretion of K* and H* ions into the urine. The loss of H* ions in urine lowers the urinary pH, resulting in paradoxical aciduria

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis leads to hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis due to persistent vomiting and loss of gastric acid.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding non-competitive inhibition?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Constant Km and decreased Vmax

 

Explanation:

 

Noncompetitive inhibition has constant Km and decreased Vmax.

 

More complex noncompetitive inhibition occurs when binding of the inhibitor does affect the apparent affinity of the enzyme for substrate, causing the lines to intercept in either the third or fourth quadrants of a double-reciprocal plot.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the finding marked in the image (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bulbar urethral stricture

 

Correctly identified based on the image, this stricture is located in the bulbar region of the urethra, just below the prostate and above the penile segment.

 

This is a urethrogram, a type of radiographic study used to evaluate the urethra. The narrowing seen in the image is consistent with a bulbar urethral stricture, which typically occurs in the part of the urethra that runs through the bulb of the penis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prostatomegaly: This would show an enlarged prostate, which typically does not affect the urethra directly on a urethrogram unless there is significant compression or involvement of the prostatic urethra.

 

Option B. Membranous urethral stricture: This type of stricture would occur in the membranous segment of the urethra, which is located between the prostate and the bulbous urethra. The location in this image does not correspond to that segment.

 

Option D. Normal urethra: This would show an unobstructed and uniformly calibred urethral passage, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Urethral strictures, particularly in the bulbar region, are commonly evaluated and diagnosed with a urethrogram, which provides clear visualization of any narrowing or obstruction along the urethral tract.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child brought to the OPD with fever and a rash spreading from the face, behind cheeks, and buccal mucosa to other body parts. On examination, Koplik's spot is present. Mark the correct diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles

 

Measles/Rubeola

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rubella: The rash of rubella is similar in distribution to that of measles (rubeola) but it is less intensely red and confluent. Forchheimer spots (Red spots over palate) may be present.

 

 

Option C. Varicella: Varicella presents with rash which appears 24-48 hrs after prodromal symptoms, then rapidly to face & trunk. There are papules, vesicles & crusted vesicles, Centripetal distribution with greatest on trunk.

 

 

Option D. Mumps: Mumps presents with Painful enlargement of salivary gland, ear ache, jaw tenderness while chewing, dryness of mouth.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Koplik spots and a characteristic rash that begins on the forehead behind the ears and spreads to the torso and extremities are pathognomonic for measles.

questions.text: The following instrument is used for: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myringotomy

 

Myringotomy is done by a sharp myringotome as shown in the image. Myringotome is a surgical knife used for paracentesis of the eardrum.

 

Myringotomy is most commonly done for serous otitis media in the anteroinferior quadrant radially. Sometimes, grommet insertion is done through the opening made by myringotome in the tympanic membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septoplasty: This procedure corrects a deviated nasal septum, involving different instruments primarily for reshaping the nasal structure, not for ear-related surgeries.

 

Option B. Myringoplasty: This is a procedure to repair a perforation of the tympanic membrane but does not typically use a myringotome; instead, it uses tools for patching or grafting the membrane.

 

Option D. Adenoidectomy: This surgery involves the removal of the adenoids located in the upper part of the throat behind the nose, using different instruments like curettes or microdebriders, not a myringotome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The myringotome is crucial for performing a myringotomy, allowing for precise incisions in the tympanic membrane to address issues such as serous otitis media. The instrument's design facilitates targeted, clean cuts to insert grommets if needed.

questions.text: After abstaining from alcohol for three days, a patient presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. In this case, what is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium tremens

 

The described clinical picture is consistent with Delirium tremens (DT). DT is a severe and potentially life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal. It typically appears 48 to 72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by agitation, disorientation, paranoid delusions, tremors, autonomic hyperactivity (such as tachycardia and hypertension), and visual or tactile hallucinations. It can be fatal if not treated promptly and properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's encephalopathy: It is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, often seen in chronic alcoholics. Symptoms include ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and confusion.

 

Option C. Korsakoff psychosis: It is a chronic neurologic sequelae of alcoholism resulting from prolonged thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by amnesia, confabulation, and lack of insight.

 

Option D. Alcohol-induced psychosis: It is a rare complication where patients present with hallucinations after heavy, prolonged alcohol consumption but without other features of withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276-277.

questions.text: A patient presents with uveitis and sacroiliitis. What is most likely associated with it? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HLA B27

 

The presentation of uveitis along with sacroiliitis is a classic manifestation of seronegative spondyloarthropathy, which is strongly associated with HLA-B27. These conditions are characterized by:

 

  • Inflammatory back pain
  • Early morning stiffness lasting more than one hour
  • Pain and stiffness that improve with exercise and worsen with rest
  • Anterior uveitis as the most common extra-articular manifestation
  • Sacroiliitis
  • Peripheral arthritis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HLA B8: Incorrect. Associated with good prognosis in sarcoidosis, not spondyloarthropathy

 

Option C. HLA B5: Incorrect. Associated with Behçet's disease

 

Option D. HLA B51: Incorrect. Also associated with Behçet's disease

 

Educational Objective:

 

HLA-B27 is strongly associated with seronegative spondyloarthropathies, particularly when patients present with the combination of uveitis and sacroiliitis.

questions.text: Cutis marmorata occurs due to? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Exposure to cold temperature

 

  • Cutis marmorata, also known as physiological livedo reticularis, describes the pinkish-blue mottled or marbled appearance of the skin that occurs when exposed to cold temperatures.

 

Fig: Cutis marmorata

 

  • During infancy, about half of all children exhibit a noticeable marbling pattern on their skin when exposed to cooler temperatures.
  • This effect arises from the simultaneous dilation and contraction of the superficial capillaries and may continue throughout early childhood.
  • However, the skin returns to its regular appearance when warmed again, indicating that this is a natural physiological response and does not necessitate any intervention.
  • Nevertheless, persistent cutis marmorata may be observed in individuals with trisomies 18 and 21.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exposure to hot temperature

 

 

Erythema Ab Igne over thigh

 

 

Option B. An adverse reaction to drugs: They can cause various skin manifestations, including rashes, urticaria, or specific reactions like Stevens-Johnson syndrome, but not cutis marmorata.

 

Option D. Humidity: It is not known to cause cutis marmorata. High humidity can lead to other skin issues like sweating and chafing, but it does not cause the vascular changes seen in cutis marmorata.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cutis marmorata is a skin condition characterized by a marbled appearance of the skin, resulting from exposure to cold temperatures due to the vascular response of constriction and dilation.

 

References

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Chapter 25, Page no 125.7

 

Question Level – Intermediate

Question Id-7447 Unique Key-Q6575185

questions.text: According to the latest AHA guidelines, what is the sixth link added to the "Chain of Survival" in CPR? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Recovery

 

The Chain of Survival is a series of critical steps that improve survival in cardiac arrest cases. The American Heart Association (AHA) recently updated the chain by adding a sixth link: Recovery.

 

Updated Chain of Survival: (Out of hospital cardiac arrest)

 

  1. Early recognition and activation of emergency response system
  2. Early CPR with high-quality chest compressions
  3. Rapid defibrillation
  4. Advanced resuscitation by emergency medical services (EMS)
  5. Post-cardiac arrest care in a hospital setting
  6. Recovery phase for physical and emotional rehabilitation

 

 

The Recovery phase focuses on post-resuscitation care, including physical rehabilitation, psychological support, and long-term follow-up to improve the patient’s quality of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early CPR: CPR is already part of the existing chain but is not the newly added sixth link.

 

Option B. Post-cardiac arrest care: This is an essential part of the chain but was already included before the update.

 

Option C. Post MI care: Management after a myocardial infarction (MI) is important but not specific to cardiac arrest care.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The American Heart Association (AHA) has updated the Chain of Survival to include a sixth link: Recovery. This emphasizes the importance of post-cardiac arrest rehabilitation, psychological support, and long-term follow-up.

choices.text: Decreased number of Lactobacilli
Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium
pH > 6.8
Epithelial thinning

questions.text: Which of the following is true about vaginal changes in a normal pregnancy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium

 

  • Vaginal epithelium increases the metabolism of glycogen in pregnancy.
  • It leads to decrease in pH and makes the vaginal epithelium more acidic
  • This is because of increased lactobacilli

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased number of Lactobacilli: The number of lactobacilli are increased in the reproductive age group especially in pregnancy

 

Option C. pH > 6.8: Vaginal pH in pregnancy is acidic

 

 

Option D. Epithelial thinning: Estrogen increases the vaginal thickness in pregnancy. The vagina becomes thin in the absence of estrogen (like in menopause)

 

Educational Objective:

 

During pregnancy, the vaginal epithelium increases glycogen metabolism, leading to a more acidic environment that promotes the growth of Lactobacilli and helps protect against infections.

 

Ref: Page no 20, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Who proposed the theory of multifactorial causation of disease? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans.  (b) Pettenkoffer

 

  • The theory of multifactorial causation of disease was proposed by Patten Koffer (also spelled as Pettenkoffer). This theory recognizes that diseases result from the interaction of multiple factors rather than a single cause. 
  • The multifactorial causation model demonstrates how various factors contribute collectively to disease development through reactions at the cellular level, providing a more comprehensive understanding of disease etiology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Louis Pasteur: He proposed the Germ Theory of Disease, which attributes diseases to specific microorganisms, not the multifactorial causation theory.

 

Option C. Fracastorius: Not associated with any of the major disease causation theories in epidemiology.

 

Option D. Aristotle: He proposed the Theory of Spontaneous Generation, which incorrectly suggested that living organisms could arise from non-living matter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The multifactorial causation theory represents a significant advancement in understanding disease etiology by recognizing that most diseases result from complex interactions of multiple causal factors rather than single causes, moving beyond the limitations of the germ theory.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with chest pain and shortness of breath. An ECG was taken in the emergency and was shown. What is the likely diagnosis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior MI

 

The patient's ECG shows classic signs of a posterior myocardial infarction (MI). The characteristic features of posterior MI in leads V1, V2 and (±) V3 include a tall R wave, ST depression, and upright T wave. These features suggest a mirror image of an infarction in the posterior wall of the left ventricle. While definitive diagnosis of a posterior MI typically involves additional leads (V7, V8, V9), the observed patterns in leads V2 and V3 are indicative of this condition.

 

In the provided case, the absence of ST elevation rules out an acute STEMI. NSTEMI and unstable angina can only be differentiated by cardiac biomarkers such as troponins, which are not mentioned here. Acute myocarditis would typically present with non-specific ECG changes and a relevant clinical history, such as a recent viral infection, which is not present in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NSTEMI:  NSTEMI (Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction) can present with similar symptoms but requires positive cardiac troponins for diagnosis. The absence of troponin data makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option B. Unstable Angina: Unstable angina presents with similar symptoms but without elevation of cardiac biomarkers. As mentioned, differentiating between NSTEMI and unstable angina is not possible without troponin levels, which are not provided.

 

Option D. Acute Myocarditis: Acute myocarditis would typically present with a history of viral infection and can show non-specific ECG changes, often including sinus tachycardia. The patient's history and ECG findings do not support this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of tall R waves, ST depression, and upright T waves in leads V2 and V3 are indicative of a posterior myocardial infarction.

questions.text: A child with a history of night-blindness presented to you with the following findings. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Phrynoderma

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of a child with night blindness and multiple hyperkeratotic papules on the elbows, as depicted in the image, raises suspicion of a diagnosis called phrynoderma or toad-skin. This condition is often linked to a deficiency of vitamin A (VAD).
  • It is characterized by the development of keratotic follicular papules, initially appearing on the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral upper arms, and subsequently spreading to the extensor surfaces of the extremities, shoulders, abdomen, back, buttocks, face, and posterior neck.
  • While originally reported in association with vitamin A deficiency, phrynoderma is a non-specific finding that can also be observed in deficiencies of B-complex vitamins, vitamin C, vitamin E, essential fatty acids (EFA deficiency), protein-energy malnutrition (PEM), and general states of malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Keratosis pilaris:

  • Description: Keratosis pilaris is a common, benign skin condition that manifests as tiny, rough-feeling bumps on the skin, often likened to "chicken skin." It frequently occurs on the upper arms, thighs, or cheeks.
  • It usually presents during puberty. Perifollicular erythema in addition to follicular plugging
  • Favors the upper outer arms and the thighs, but lacks discrete clusters. Treatment is purely reserved for cosmetic purposes.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis:  While keratosis pilaris can appear on the upper arms close to the elbows, it's not specifically associated with night-blindness or vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option C. Darier disease:

  • Description: Darier disease is a rare, genetic skin disorder characterized by small, hard bumps on the skin, especially on the chest, back, and forehead. These may be yellowish in color and often have a foul odor.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis While Darier disease causes papules, it is not associated with night-blindness. Other features of Darier disease are also not mentioned in the question.

 

Option D. Follicular eczema:

  • Description: This is a variant of eczema (atopic dermatitis) that specifically affects the hair follicles, leading to itchy, inflamed skin.
  • Reasons it might not fit: Though follicular eczema can cause papules, the association with night-blindness is not seen. Eczema would typically be associated with itching and possibly a history of allergies or atopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical students preparing for residency, it is crucial to associate the findings of follicular hyperkeratotic papules, especially when coupled with systemic symptoms such as night-blindness, with phrynoderma, a condition related to vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page no 63.8

questions.text: A protein solution forms a precipitate when heated to around 40°C, which then dissolves again at higher temperatures. This protein is most likely to be: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bence Jones Protein

 

Explanation:

 

Bence Jones proteins are immunoglobulin light chains that exhibit a unique property of thermal precipitation. They precipitate when heated to approximately 40-60°C but redissolve upon further heating to boiling point (100°C). This unusual behavior is a classic diagnostic feature used to identify these proteins in urine samples. Bence Jones proteins are found in multiple myeloma and related plasma cell disorders, where there is excessive production of monoclonal light chains that are filtered through the kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cryoglobulins: These are immunoglobulins that precipitate at cold temperatures (below 37°C) and redissolve upon warming. This behavior is opposite to that described in the question. Cryoglobulins are associated with conditions like hepatitis C infection, autoimmune disorders, and lymphoproliferative diseases.

 

Option C. Complement: This refers to a system of plasma proteins that plays a key role in immune responses. Complement proteins do not exhibit the thermal precipitation and resolubilization pattern described in the question. They are typically denatured irreversibly when heated.

 

Option D. Alpha-2 macroglobulins: These are large plasma proteins that function as protease inhibitors. They do not show the characteristic precipitation at 40°C with redissolution at higher temperatures. Alpha-2 macroglobulins are part of the acute phase response and are typically denatured when heated.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The thermoreversible precipitation property of Bence Jones proteins—precipitating at approximately 40-60°C and redissolving at higher temperatures—is a unique diagnostic feature that distinguishes these immunoglobulin light chains from other proteins and serves as a valuable marker for plasma cell disorders.

questions.text: During total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, which of the following steps will not lead to hoarseness of voice?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dissection of strap muscles

 

Hoarseness of voice after thyroidectomy is generally due to injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), which controls the vocal cords. The RLN is located near the thyroid gland, and careful surgical technique is necessary to avoid damaging it. The strap muscles, which are located anterior to the thyroid gland, are far from the path of the RLN, so dissecting these muscles will not result in hoarseness of voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option  A. Dissection of Beahr’s triangle: The recurrent laryngeal nerve forms the anterior boundary of Beahr’s triangle, making it susceptible to injury during dissection, which can lead to hoarseness.

 

Option B. Dissection of Zuckerkandl tubercle: The Zuckerkandl tubercle is closely associated with the recurrent laryngeal nerve, so dissection in this area can risk nerve injury and subsequent hoarseness.

 

Option D. Ligation of Superior thyroid artery: This procedure is generally more likely to affect the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve rather than the recurrent laryngeal nerve, but in cases of anatomical variation, there is a small risk that the RLN could be affected, potentially leading to hoarseness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dissection of the strap muscles during thyroidectomy does not involve the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and therefore, will not cause hoarseness of voice.

questions.text: A patient presents with a perforation in the tympanic membrane. During the evaluation, a Rinne test is performed. What is the expected outcome of the Rinne test in this case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Negative

 

Perforation of the tympanic membrane results in conductive hearing loss because the sound waves cannot be properly transmitted through the middle ear. In cases of conductive hearing loss, the Rinne test, which compares air conduction (AC) to bone conduction (BC), will be negative. This occurs because bone conduction is perceived as louder than air conduction, indicating a conductive defect. The negative Rinne test is characteristic of any lesion or abnormality affecting the external ear, tympanic membrane, or middle ear, as these structures are responsible for sound conduction.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive: A positive Rinne test indicates that air conduction is louder than bone conduction, which is normal or seen in sensorineural hearing loss, not conductive hearing loss like that caused by a tympanic membrane perforation.

 

Option C. Indeterminate: This is not a standard result for the Rinne test. The Rinne test is typically either positive or negative, and "indeterminate" does not correctly describe the results related to tympanic membrane perforation.

 

Option D. Equivocal: An equivocal Rinne test result suggests equal loudness of air and bone conduction, which is not typically associated with tympanic membrane perforation. This term is not commonly used in describing Rinne test outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A perforation in the tympanic membrane causes conductive hearing loss, which is characterized by a negative Rinne test, where bone conduction is heard louder than air conduction.

questions.text: A patient with a history of strenuous exercise skipped a meal and later consumed alcohol at a party. Alcohol inhibits which of the following biochemical processes, potentially leading to hypoglycemia: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gluconeogenesis

 

The question describes a clinical scenario where alcohol consumption after exercise and skipping meals leads to hypoglycemia. Alcohol inhibits gluconeogenesis through several mechanisms:

 

  1. Alcohol metabolism produces excess NADH through: 
    • Conversion of alcohol to acetaldehyde (ADH reaction)
    • Conversion of acetaldehyde to acetate (ALDH reaction)
  2. Excess NADH causes: 
    • Conversion of pyruvate to lactate
    • Conversion of oxaloacetate to malate
  3. This leads to depletion of pyruvate and oxaloacetate, which are essential substrates for gluconeogenesis
  4. Since the patient has exercised and skipped meals, glycogen stores are already depleted, making gluconeogenesis crucial for maintaining blood glucose

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycogenolysis - Incorrect

 

  • Alcohol does not directly inhibit glycogenolysis
  • However, after strenuous exercise and skipping meals, glycogen stores would already be depleted

 

Option C. Hexose Monophosphate (HMP) Shunt - Incorrect

 

  • Alcohol does not directly affect the HMP shunt
  • HMP shunt is primarily involved in NADPH production and not glucose homeostasis

 

Option D. Ketone Body Formation - Incorrect

 

  • Alcohol actually promotes ketone body formation due to increased Acetyl-CoA from alcohol metabolism
  • This leads to alcoholic ketosis rather than inhibition

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcohol consumption inhibits gluconeogenesis by creating a high NADH/NAD+ ratio, which depletes gluconeogenic substrates (pyruvate and oxaloacetate), potentially leading to hypoglycemia, especially when glycogen stores are depleted.

choices.text: Do USG- check for congenital abnormality, gestational age and sex. But don’t tell the sex to the mother.
Do USG- check for congenital abnormality, gestational age and sex. Tell the sex to the mother.
Do USG- check for congenital abnormality, and gestational age. Don’t check for sex.

questions.text: A G5L4 woman has 4 daughters. She now comes for USG examination of her fetus and asks for sex determination. What will you do? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Do USG- check for congenital abnormality, and gestational age. Don’t check for sex.

 

According to the Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (PCPNDT) Act in many countries, including India, determining and disclosing the sex of the fetus during ultrasound is illegal and strictly prohibited, regardless of the patient’s family history or number of children of a specific sex. The purpose of the ultrasound should be solely to assess the health of the fetus, including checking for congenital abnormalities and determining the gestational age.

 

Radiologists may, in practice, be aware of the fetal sex when checking for specific congenital abnormalities that are sex-linked; however, neither the act of checking for sex nor disclosing the sex to the parents is legally permissible. The correct approach, as per the law, is to conduct the ultrasound for medical indications only and not involve fetal sex determination.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Do USG- check for congenital abnormality, gestational age and sex. But don’t tell the sex to the mother: This option is incorrect as checking the sex is itself illegal under the PCPNDT Act, even if it is not disclosed to the parents.

 

Option B. Do USG- check for congenital abnormality, gestational age and sex. Tell the sex to the mother: This option is both legally and ethically wrong, as checking and disclosing fetal sex is prohibited by law.

 

Option D. Don’t Do the USG: This option is incorrect because conducting an ultrasound for assessing fetal health (such as checking for congenital abnormalities and gestational age) is appropriate and medically necessary, provided it does not include sex determination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The law prohibits both the determination and disclosure of fetal sex during ultrasound examinations. Ultrasound should be performed strictly for medical indications such as assessing fetal health, detecting congenital abnormalities, and determining gestational age, without involving sex determination.

choices.text: Prevents atelectasis of lung and alveolar collapse
Reduces CO2 in alveoli
Decreases inspiratory pressure
Increases venous return and thus maintains cardiac output

questions.text: In a patient on mechanical ventilation and placed in prone position which of the following about PEEP is true? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prevents atelectasis of lung and alveolar collapse

 

Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) is a crucial component of mechanical ventilation, particularly in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or other conditions leading to alveolar collapse. PEEP works by maintaining a certain amount of pressure in the lungs at the end of expiration, which helps to keep the alveoli open, preventing their collapse (atelectasis). This is especially important in the prone position, where the distribution of ventilation can be more uniform, improving oxygenation and lung mechanics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduces CO2 in alveoli: This option is incorrect because the primary role of PEEP is not to reduce CO2 levels in the alveoli but to prevent alveolar collapse and improve oxygenation. CO2 removal is more dependent on ventilation rate and tidal volume.

 

Option C. Decreases inspiratory pressure: This option is incorrect because PEEP typically increases the baseline pressure in the lungs, which can actually increase the overall mean airway pressure during inspiration. It does not decrease inspiratory pressure.

 

Option D. Increases venous return and thus maintains cardiac output: This option is incorrect because, in fact, PEEP can decrease venous return due to the increased intrathoracic pressure it creates. This decrease in venous return can lead to a reduction in cardiac output, especially in patients with pre-existing cardiovascular compromise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PEEP is primarily used to prevent alveolar collapse (atelectasis) and maintain lung recruitment, especially in conditions like ARDS or when the patient is positioned prone during mechanical ventilation.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with right-sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis for the past 6 months. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) JNA

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that occurs almost exclusively in adolescent males. The typical presentation includes nasal obstruction and recurrent episodes of epistaxis (nosebleeds).

Other Options:

 

Option B. Allergic Rhinitis: Nasal obstruction but no recurrent epistaxis.

 

Option C. Coagulation Disorder: Bleeding from multiple sites, not specific to nasal obstruction in adolescent males.

 

Option D. Antrochoanal Polyp: Nasal obstruction without recurrent epistaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is the most likely diagnosis for a 13-year-old boy with right-sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis, as it commonly presents in adolescent males with these symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK9 inhibitor? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Evolocumab
 

Alirocumab and Evolocumab are PCSK9 (proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9) inhibitors. These works by inhibiting the PCSK9 enzyme which is responsible for degradation of LDL receptors in the liver. Therefore, these drugs lead to an increased number of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors on liver cells and a subsequent decrease in LDL cholesterol levels in the blood. PCSK9 inhibitors are used for lowering cholesterol levels, particularly in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or those who are at high risk for cardiovascular disease and have not adequately responded to statins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe works by inhibiting the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine, which leads to a reduction in the total amount of cholesterol presented to the liver. It does not inhibit PCSK9.

 

Option C. Bempedoic Acid: Bempedoic acid is a relatively new cholesterol-lowering medication. It inhibits ATP citrate lyase, an enzyme involved in cholesterol synthesis, but it is not a PCSK9 inhibitor.

 

Option D. Clofibrate: Clofibrate is a fibrate used to lower lipid levels, particularly triglycerides. It works by activating peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs) and does not inhibit PCSK9.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Evolocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor that works by blocking the PCSK9 enzyme, leading to increased LDL receptor availability on liver cells and reduced LDL cholesterol levels in the blood.

questions.text: What alternative drug would you use for cardiac arrest if epinephrine is not effective? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amiodarone

 

Epinephrine and amiodarone are the two main drugs approved by the American Heart Association for the resuscitation of a cardiac arrest patient.
Dose of epinephrine = 1 mg every 3-5 min IV
Dose of Amiodarone = 300 mg IV bolus dose

 

  • Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic drug that is used to treat and prevent various types of arrhythmias.
  • For cardiac arrest, amiodarone is particularly recommended for ventricular fibrillation (VF) and pulseless ventricular tachycardia (VT) when initial defibrillation attempts have failed.
  • It acts by prolonging the action potential and refractory period in myocardial tissue, and it also has vasodilatory effects.
  • The initial recommended dose for cardiac arrest is 300 mg IV push.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vasopressin: Vasopressin is a synthetic peptide that stimulates V1 receptors, leading to vasoconstriction. It was once considered as an alternative to epinephrine for cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), but more recent guidelines from organizations like the American Heart Association (AHA) have moved away from recommending its routine use in cardiac arrest. This is due to a lack of evidence showing a significant improvement in survival to hospital discharge.

 

Option B. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that blocks the effects of the vagus nerve on the heart. It increases the heart rate and was previously used in the treatment of asystole and pulseless electrical activity (PEA) cardiac arrest. However, more recent AHA guidelines no longer recommend atropine for routine use in these situations due to lack of evidence for its effectiveness.

 

Option D. Adenosine: Adenosine is a drug that is primarily used to treat certain types of supraventricular tachycardias (SVT). It works by slowing down the electrical activity in the heart, which can temporarily stop the heart, allowing it to "reset" itself to a normal rhythm. While adenosine can be very effective for its indicated uses, it's not typically used in the setting of cardiac arrest.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Amiodarone is an effective alternative drug for cardiac arrest, particularly for ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia when initial defibrillation attempts have failed.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Abscess

 

The provided MRI images show a ring-enhancing lesion with bright white areas on diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI), which indicates diffusion restriction. Diffusion restriction on DWI is characteristic of a brain abscess. Brain abscesses typically appear as ring-enhancing lesions with diffusion restriction due to the presence of pus, which restricts the movement of water molecules. The absence of bony structures and clear visualization of the brain on the MRI sequence also confirm that this is a DWI image, where bright areas represent restricted diffusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberculomas: Tuberculomas often present as multiple ring-enhancing lesions that may conglomerate, and do not show the same characteristic diffusion restriction seen in abscesses. They have a different imaging pattern and usually do not exhibit a single, well-defined ring-enhancing lesion with prominent diffusion restriction.

 

Option C. Cryptococcomas: These lesions are commonly found in the basal ganglia and have a soap-bubble appearance rather than a ring enhancement. Cryptococcomas are typically not associated with the intense diffusion restriction seen in abscesses.

 

Option D. NCC (Neurocysticercosis): NCC lesions often have a characteristic central scolex, which is not visible in this image. The presence of a scolex is a key feature for diagnosing NCC, and the absence of this finding makes NCC less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brain abscesses present as ring-enhancing lesions with diffusion restriction on diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI), appearing bright white on DWI due to restricted water movement caused by pus accumulation.

questions.text: Cytotoxic and expired medications are appropriately discarded through: [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Incineration

 

  • Expired and cytotoxic drugs should be disposed of using specific methods, such as incineration, encapsulation, or plasma pyrolysis, and should be returned to the manufacturer if possible.
  • Other medications can also be disposed of using similar methods.
  • The use of yellow bags is common for hazardous waste to ensure proper handling and disposal by trained personnel.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A female patient presents with swollen Bartholin glands. Discharging pus showed Gram-negative intracellular diplococci. Which is the organism?(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a Gram-negative diplococcus that is often found intracellularly within neutrophils. It is a common cause of sexually transmitted infections, including infections of the Bartholin glands. The typical presentation includes swelling and pus discharge, which is consistent with the given clinical scenario.

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is characterized by its kidney or bean shape and lack of a capsule, unlike Neisseria meningitidis, which is capsulated. It is known for causing sexually transmitted infections, including those affecting the genital tract, such as Bartholin gland abscesses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chlamydia: Although Chlamydia can cause genital infections, it is not a Gram-negative diplococcus. Instead, it is an obligate intracellular bacterium with a unique developmental cycle.

 

Option C. Chancroid: Caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, chancroid is a Gram-negative bacillus and not a diplococcus.

 

Option D. Syphilis: Caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete, which is not a Gram-negative diplococcus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a Gram-negative intracellular diplococcus, is the causative agent of gonorrhea and can infect the Bartholin glands, leading to swelling and pus discharge.

choices.text: Remove IUD gently, then do MTP
