questions.text: A 29-year-old woman had an IUD inserted at a PHC. After a few months, she conceives. On examination, the IUD is still in place. She wants to continue with her pregnancy. Next best step of management is? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Remove IUD gently

 

In cases where a woman becomes pregnant with an intrauterine device (IUD) still in place and wishes to continue with the pregnancy, the standard approach is to gently remove the IUD if the threads are visible and accessible. Removal of the IUD reduces the risk of complications such as infection, preterm labor, and spontaneous abortion. Gently pulling the IUD threads minimizes trauma and associated risks.

 

However, it is important to counsel the patient about the increased risk of spontaneous abortion even after the removal of the IUD, but removal is generally recommended to avoid ongoing complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Remove IUD gently, then do MTP: This is incorrect because performing Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) is not mandatory and cannot be enforced unless the patient chooses it. The primary goal here is to safely remove the IUD, not to proceed directly with MTP.

 

Option C. Do MTP directly: This option is incorrect because the patient explicitly wants to continue the pregnancy. MTP should not be performed without the patient’s consent, and it is not a management step in this case unless requested by the patient.

 

Option D. Leave IUD in situ: Leaving the IUD in place is not advisable as it poses a high risk of adverse outcomes, including infections, miscarriage, and preterm birth. The safest option is to remove the IUD if possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If a woman conceives with an IUD in place and wishes to continue the pregnancy, the IUD should be gently removed to minimize the risk of complications.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female labourer complains of soft, fluctuating swelling in front of the knee, directly over the patella. She reports discomfort and difficulty while moving her knee. MRI results confirm the findings. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Housemaid’s knee

 

  • Prepatellar bursitis or housemaid’s knee is the swelling and inflammation of the anterior knee bursa associated with pain with kneeling. 
  • The bursa affected lies anterior to patella. 
  • It occurs commonly due to excessive kneeling and also seen in wrestlers. 
  • On MRI, an oval shaped fluid-filled sac is seen anterior to the patella. 
  • The wall of the bursa may show increased thickness and irregularity.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subdermal abscess: A subdermal abscess in the knee is a pocket of pus that forms under the skin on the knee. It is usually caused by a bacterial infection. Symptoms of a subdermal abscess knee include pain, swelling, redness, and warmth in the knee. The abscess may also be visible as a raised, red bump on the skin.

 

 

Option C. Gout: Gout is an inflammatory arthropathy caused by long-standing hyperuricemia. Patients are usually asymptomatic for many years before developing symptoms and before radiographic evidence of disease. The first metatarsophalangeal joint is the most commonly involved joint. Involvement of the knee is not uncommon, but involvement of the patella is rare. MRI may demonstrate changes of gout arthritis including nodular thickening of the distal quadriceps tendon and erosion of the superior aspect of the patella. There can also be diffuse thickening of the prepatellar soft tissues , patellar tendon, and nodular thickening of the iliotibial band. 

 

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory autoimmune disease of unknown etiology that affects approximately 1% of the world population, with approximately 50% of adults being unable to work within 10 years of disease onset. The disease involves synovial joints and leads to progressive joint destruction. The knee joint is commonly involved in RA. Damage to the cartilage is associated with irreversible physical disability. The articular cartilage of the femoral condyles is destroyed early in the disease process, including roughening, softening, and fibrillation. MRI is the best non‐invasive modality to evaluate RA. It identifies synovial thickening, including inflammatory and fibrous proliferation, joint effusion, marginal erosions and subchondral cysts, periarticular soft tissue swelling, popliteal cysts, and tendon thickening. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows an inflammation anterior to the patella. 
  • This is seen in prepatellar bursitis, also called housemaid’s knee.

questions.text: What is the infective dose range for Salmonella Typhi? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 10² to 10⁵ bacilli

 

Explanation:

 

The infective dose for Salmonella Typhi falls within the range of 10² to 10⁵ bacilli. This is a relatively low infectious dose compared to many other enteric pathogens, which explains why typhoid fever can be transmitted through contaminated food or water even with modest bacterial loads.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. One bacillus: This is incorrect because a single bacterial cell of S. Typhi is insufficient to cause infection. Even highly virulent pathogens typically require multiple organisms to establish infection and overcome host defenses.

 

Option B. 1 to 10 bacilli: This is incorrect because this range is too low for S. Typhi to establish infection. While S. Typhi has a relatively low infectious dose, it still requires more than 10 organisms.

 

Option D. 10⁸ to 10¹⁰ bacilli: This is incorrect because this range is too high. Such a high bacterial load would be required for organisms with low pathogenicity, unlike S. Typhi which can cause infection with a much lower dose (10² to 10⁵).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Salmonella Typhi has a moderate infectious dose requirement (10² to 10⁵ bacilli), which contributes to its efficiency as a pathogen and explains why typhoid fever can spread relatively easily through contaminated water and food supplies.

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent kidney stones. The microscopic examination of the urine specimen is shown below. Which of the following is not seen in the urine of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cysteine

 

  • Cystine is the oxidized dimer form of cysteine (two cysteine molecules joined by a disulfide bond).
  • Cystine, not cysteine, is excreted in urine and precipitates to form stones.
  • Therefore, cysteine is not typically found in the urine of cystinuric patients in significant amounts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arginine: Arginine is an amino acid and is not typically associated with kidney stone formation. It is usually found in the urine.

 

Option B. Lysine: Lysine is another amino acid and is not commonly linked to kidney stone formation. It is typically present in the urine.

 

Option C. Cystine: Cystine is an amino acid that is known to form cystine stones, a type of kidney stone. Therefore, cystine can be found in the urine of patients with cystine stones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystinuria: Cystinuria is one of the inborn errors of metabolism included in the Garrod’s tetrad. It is an autosomal recessive condition.

 

The disorder is attributed to the deficiency in transport of amino acids Signs and symptoms include:

 

  1. Abnormal excretion of cystine and to a lesser extent lysine, ornithine and arginine. Hence the condition is also called Cystine-lysinuria.
  2. Crystalluria and calculi formation. In acidic pH, cystine crystals are formed in urine
  3. Obstructive uropathy, which may lead to renal insufficiency
  4. Cyanide-Nitroprusside Test is a screening test. Urine is made alkaline with ammonium hydroxide and sodium cyanide is added. Cystine, if present, is reduced to cysteine. Then add sodium nitroprusside to get a magenta-red colored complex. Specific aminoaciduria may be confirmed by chromatography.
  5. Treatment is to increase urinary volume by increasing fluid intake. Solubility of cystine is increased by alkalinization of urine by giving sodium bicarbonate.
